Description.val:
The Eastern Range (ER) at Patrick Air Force Base/Cape Canaveral AFS, FL, and the Western Range (WR) at Vandenberg AFB, CA, make up the Spacelift Range System (SLRS), also known as the Launch and Test Range System (LTRS).  The SLRS provides tracking, telemetry, communications, command destruct, and other capabilities to safely conduct national security, civil and commercial spacelift operations; intercontinental and sea-launched ballistic missile test launches; national missile defense tests; and aeronautical tests.  Decreasing reliability and sustainability of aging range equipment leads to higher operations and maintenance (O&M) costs and increased risk of launch delays.  

The AF is addressing range shortcomings through modernization and sustainment efforts.  Modernization addresses requirements to make the ranges more flexible, centralized, and capable of parallel operations to support evolving launch and test demands.  Sustainment projects replace aging equipment with newer, more reliable and sustainable equipment.  In combination these efforts increase responsiveness to launch demands, enhance range safety, standardize logistics support, and reduce O&M costs.  Associated RDT&E, AF funding is in program element 0305182F, Spacelift Range System, Project 674137, LTRS Modernization.  The AF is modernizing and sustaining range systems (command destruct; communications; range safety; meteorological; radar; telemetry; optics/imaging; data handling; planning and scheduling; timing and sequencing; and surveillance) via following contracts: 

1) The Spacelift Range Systems Contract (SLRSC) will complete telemetry, radar, and command destruct instrumentation site modernization projects through FY13. 

2) The LTRS Integrated Support Contract (LISC), to be awarded in FY14, will continue sustainment and logistics efforts previously done by the Spacelift Range System Contract (SLRSC) through FY13, in combination with and consolidating operations and maintenance (O&M) efforts previously done by separate O&M contracts at each of the ranges.  Additionally, LISC will support integration, testing, and acceptance of Eastern and Western Range telemetry and radar site instrumentation modernization efforts not completed on the SLRSC by its end date.  The AF is requiring an increased percentage of LISC operations, maintenance, and sustainment work to be performed by small business subcontractors.  Also, the AF is segregating non-mission administrative support communications for both ranges and non-mission elements of downrange base operating support for ER as a LISC small business prime set-aside contract.  

3) The Systems Engineering and Integration (SE&I) contract supporting the program management office will expand systems engineering efforts as the government expands its role as lead systems integrator.  These efforts will provide requirements analysis, architectures/roadmaps, engineering management plans, interface control documents, etc., to capture legacy system configuratons and to guide ongoing modernization and sustainment efforts under LISC and other AF, DoD, and GSA contracts.

4) The Range Command Destruct Modernization (RCDM) contract will enhance range central command remoting systems and flight termination signal systems to enable reliable generation and transmission of secure, digitized flight termination signals.

5) The Modernization of ER Network (MEN) and WR Modernization of Network (WMN) contracts, small business-set asides, will upgrade ER and WR Networks to Internet Protocol v4/6 (IPv4/6).  The AF is accomplishing this conversion to IPv4/6 in conjunction with common AF information transport system upgrades (to include fiber, copper and wireless components) being undertaken concurrently at the ranges via AF-wide communications programs.  These efforts will ensure compliance with OSD policies and standards for net centricity and will address global information grid interface, information assurance, digital encryption, internet protocol usage, and obsolescence issues.  

6) Other DoD and GSA contracts will modernize range capabilities not covered by current efforts (e.g., meteorological; optics/imaging; data handling; planning and scheduling; timing/sequencing; surveillance; etc.), as dictated by the evolving range architecture being driven by changing operational requirements, priorities, and capabilities.

Funding for this exhibit is in PE 0305182F.

Justification.val:
1.  SLRS MODERNIZATION:

a) RANGE COMMAND DESTRUCT MODERNIZATION: FY14 funds will pay for conversion of Eastern Range flight termination systems to digital, fully encrypted capabilities per NSA mandate to phase out current analog systems.  They also pay for upgrades to the Central Command Remoting System, which transports command functions from the flight safety system to the command instrumentation sites for transmission to the launch vehicle.  Both of these efforts will be via the Range Command Destruct Modernization (RCDM) contract.

b) MODERNIZATION OF ER NETWORK: FY14 funds will continue modernization of the network/infrastructure on the Eastern Range, including conversion to Internet Protocol Version 4/6 (IPv4/6), via the Modernization of ER (MEN) contract, a small business set-aside.  The AF is accomplishing this conversion to IP in close coordination with common AF information transport system upgrades (to include fiber, copper and wireless components) being undertaken concurrently at the ranges via AF-wide communications programs.
  
c) WR MODERNIZATION OF NETWORK: FY14 funds will continue modernization of the network/infrastructure on the Western Range, including conversion to Internet Protocol Version 6 (IPv6), through the WR Modernization of Network (WMN) contract, a small-business set-aside.  The AF is accomplishing this conversion to IP in close coordination with common AF information transport system upgrades (to include fiber, copper and wireless components) being undertaken concurrently at the ranges via AF-wide communications programs.  
  
2. SLRS SUSTAINMENT:

a) SLRS SUSTAINMENT PROJECTS: FY14 funds will pay for continuation of SLRS sustainment projects via LISC.  Specific projects to be accomplished depend on operational requirements and priorities, as well as reliability, maintainability, and availability status.  Sustainment projects will address the following capability areas: command destruct; telemetry; radar; range safety; communications; data handling; meteorological; optics/imaging; timing and sequencing; planning and scheduling; and surveillance.  Significant small business subcontractor involvement in these efforts is likely, given the AF requirement for increased small business subcontractor participation on LISC as a whole.  
 
b) SLRS INTERIM SUPPLY SUPPORT: FY14 funds will pay for interim supply support, to include supplies and associated interim supply support management, via LISC.
 
c) OPERATIONAL SUPPORT: FY14 funds will pay for operational space wing support to integration, test, and turnover of new systems through modernization and sustainment efforts, via LISC.
 
d) SYSTEMS ENGINEERING AND INTEGRATION: FY14 funds will continue comprehensive systems engineering and integration efforts, via the SE&I contract supporting the program management office as lead system integrator, to include systems architecture maintenance, interface control, configuration management, etc.  It will capture legacy system configuratons and guide ongoing modernization and sustainment efforts to include SLRSC completion, transition to LISC, and use of small business set aside contracts for network communications and flight termination system upgrades.  SE&I ensures modernization and sustainment efforts address operational requirements; range architecture plans; reliability, maintainability, and availabilty factors; and current OSD standards for interface IT systems. 

e) PROGRAM MANAGEMENT ADMINISTRATION (PMA): FY14 funds will pay advisory and assistance services supporting the System Program Office (SPO) and indirect support to the SPO to include information technology, education, and training support, through various contracts.

f) FFRDC ENGINEERING SUPPORT: FY14 funds will pay for FFRDC technical engineering support from Aerospace for AF management of modernization efforts and sustainment projects. 

g) INFORMATION ASSURANCE: FY14 funds will pay for information assurance certification and accreditation support through various contracts, including small business set-asides, to enable protected operation of new systems. 
 
Items requested in FY14 are identified on the following P-5s and are representative of items to be procured. Items procured during execution may change based on critical equipment needed to support current Air Force mission requirements.

Remarks.val:
- Unit quantities and costs vary widely for multiple types and configurations of equipment being procured under modernization and sustainment project cost elements each fiscal year.
- FY12 and FY13 funding breakdowns have changed since FY12 and FY13 President's Budgets due to technical delays, revised operational plans/priorities, and extended LISC preparations.

FiscalYear.@footnote: AFSPC/SMC will use FY13 funds to initiate a separate contract to modernize range command destruct systems, including Central Command Remoting Systems and Enhanced Flight Termination (encrypted/digital) Systems.
FY14 funds are for option to RCDM contract, specifics TBD.

This is option to prior year ITT Exelis, Cape Canaveral, FL, Nov 00 basic contract award.  Spacelift Range System Contract (SLRSC) includes options for: modernization and sustainment efforts; sustaining engineering; interim supply support; configuration and data management; and depot-level maintenance.

AF will use small business set-aside contract vehicles for Modernization of ER Network (MEN) and WR Modernization of Network (WMN), relying on current DoD/AF systems/solutions as much as possible.  Contract type, contractor, and location are TBD.
FY13 and FY14 funds are option to MEN small business set aside contract, specifics TBD.
FY14 funds are for option to WMN small business set aside contract, specifics TBD.
